abstracts.cdata!:
The Basic Education Project for Sudan
            had an overall moderately satisfactory outcome, with the
            performances of the Bank as well as the grantee being deemed
            moderately satisfactory as well. Of the three project
            development objective indicators, one was achieved fully,
            one partially, and one was mostly achieved. Of the four
            intermediate outcome indicators, two were fully achieved,
            while the remaining two were fully achieved as per revised
            targets, but only partially as per the original targets.
            Significant lessons learned during project implementation
            include: 1) community engagement is powerful, even in
            conflict situations; 2) targeting and resource allocation
            requires that bottom-up need assessment be balanced with
            top-down planning and monitoring; 3) data is the cornerstone
            for project targeting, implementation and result monitoring;
            4) curriculum reforms are difficult; 5) interventions to
            improve the teaching force are complex; 6) interventions to
            provide education infrastructure need to take into account
            the local market situation and the capacity of contractors
            to deliver; 7) institutional assessment needs to be integral
            part of the design; 8) ensuring high quality leadership is
            critical for the project success; 9) project institutional
            arrangements need to be clear; 10) projects, especially
            projects in more fragile states, are subject to external and
            sometimes unforeseen factors; and 11) project teams
            including both the government and the Bank need to stay
            flexible and agile.
